description:
'''Chamamé''' ([[Guarani language|Guarani]] for: party, disorder) is a [[folk music]] genre from northeast [[Argentina]] and Argentine [[Mesopotamia, Argentina|Mesopotamia]]. In 2020, Chamamé was inscribed in [[UNESCO]]'s [[Intangible cultural heritage]] list after it was nominated by Argentina in 2018.

Chamamé is also a traditional musical style appreciated in borders zone{{clarify|date=April 2024|reason=What is "borders zone"?}} of [[South America]], as [[Paraguay]] and [[Uruguay]]


[[Jesuit reductions]] in the area encouraged cultural growth that lasted until the [[Society of Jesus|Jesuits]] were expelled by the [[Spanish Crown]] in the late 18th century. Within this area, [[Yapeyú, Corrientes|Yapeyú]], [[Corrientes Province|Corrientes]] was a centre of musical culture that many point to as the birthplace of the original Chamamé. Further mixing with instruments such as the [[Classical guitar|Spanish guitar]], then the [[violin]] and the [[accordion]], finally resulted in what is currently known as "Chamamé". There are recordings of Chamamé dating back to the early 20th century, and the term 'Chamamé' was already used in 1931; this type of music, prior to that, was often referred to as the ''Corrientes [[Polka]]''.

The Chamamé, originally [[schottische]] brought by the [[Volga German]] immigrants, has considerable [[Guarani people|Guaraní]] influence, mixed with the Spanish guitar and the European [[accordion]] from those immigrants that arrived in the area at the beginning of the 20th century.

Among chamamé figures of note are [[Teresa Parodi]], [[Tránsito Cocomarola]], [[Alejandro Brittes]], [[Ramona Galarza]], and [[Chango Spasiuk]].

Chamamé arrived on stages such as [[Library of Congress|Library Of Congress]] in September 2023 with accordionist Alejandro Brittes.
